entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Go-Live Readiness: The Practical Playbook for a Safe Launch
entry.content:
The SuccessFactors Go-Live Readiness Guide

A practical guide to protect business operations in Week 1 and beyond

Go-live is not an IT milestone. It’s a business continuity event.
On Day 1, SAP SuccessFactors becomes part of payroll deadlines, onboarding commitments, approvals, compliance, and leadership reporting.

This blog is designed to be a go/no-go reference you can reuse across programs : focused on what actually breaks in production and what to do about it.

TL;DR (Executive Summary)

A go-live is “ready” when five conditions are true:

  1. Tasks work (critical processes complete end-to-end)

  2. Data trusted (fit for HR operations + decisions)

  3. Payroll protected (timing/deltas/retries controlled)

  4. Access correct (right roles, no blockers, no overexposure)

  5. Support ready (issues resolved quickly without chaos)

If any of these are not true, expect Week-1 disruption.

 Go-live readiness is operational readiness

 

Who This Is For

  • Customers going live in the next 4–12 weeks

  • Program leads who need a business-owned readiness view

  • HR Ops, Payroll, and IT teams who want fewer surprises in Week 1

1) Scope Clarity: Prevent “Surprise Scope” on Day 1

Many Week-1 tickets are not defects, they’re expectation mismatches.

Lock down Day-1 scope like a contract

  • Modules + sub-features (e.g., EC core vs Position Management vs Time Off)

  • Population (countries/legal entities, contractors, executives)

  • Processes that must work Day 1

    • Hire / rehire / termination

    • Transfer / promotion / salary change

    • Manager change + delegation

    • Recruiting → Onboarding → EC hire (if applicable)

Non-negotiable deliverable (simple but powerful)

Create a one-page “Day-1 Capabilities Sheet” by role:

  • Employee / Manager / HR Admin / HRBP / Recruiter / Payroll

If it’s not written by role, it’s not understood by users.

2) Data Migration: Data Quality Is a Business Risk (Not a Technical Detail)

Bad data breaks trust faster than any UI issue.

What you must prove before go-live

  • At least two realistic mock loads (not sample loads)

  • Validation of outcomes, not only “load succeeded”

  • Reconciliation that business accepts:

    • Headcount counts

    • Org/manager hierarchy

    • Job history sanity

    • Time off balances (if in scope)

    • Position relationships (if in scope)

Data Acceptance Criteria (example gates)

Use thresholds and hold the line:

  • 0 missing managers for active population

  • <0.5% org assignment exceptions

  • 100% active employees have user + email + manager

 Stoplights prevent “we’ll fix it later” data debt.

 

3) RBP & Access: The #1 Go-Live Ticket Generator

If RBP is wrong, everything looks broken.

What to validate

  • All roles tested with day-in-the-life scenarios

  • Edge cases tested (they will happen):

    • Matrix managers

    • Delegates/coverage

    • HR supporting multiple entities

    • Country-specific sensitive access boundaries

  • Hypercare admins have required access (no dependency bottlenecks)

Practical mitigation (works every time)

Create a Role Test Pack:

  • 10 scenarios per role

  • executed by real business testers

  • with expected results + screenshots

Most access failures are predictable and preventable.

4) Workflows & Approvals: The Quiet Go-Live Killer

Workflows break due to missing approvers, permission gaps, and real-world org changes.

What “workflow ready” means

  • Every workflow has:

    • correct step owners

    • fallback paths

    • monitoring + ownership

  • You tested top transactions end-to-end:

    • Job changes

    • Terminations

    • Manager changes

    • Compensation approvals (if applicable)

    • Recruiting approvals (if applicable)

Practical mitigation: Workflow Rescue Kit (must-have)

Define:

  • who monitors stuck items

  • how to identify the failure reason quickly

  • who can fix data vs who can restart workflows

  • escalation within hours, not days

 When approvals stall, response time matters more than documentation.

 

5) Integrations: Test Reality (Timing + Volume), Not Just Mappings

Integrations fail on timing windows, dependencies, missed deltas, and lack of monitoring ownership.

What you must validate

  • End-to-end chain:

    • Recruiting → Onboarding → EC → Payroll/IT provisioning

    • EC changes → payroll/finance downstream

    • Termination → downstream access removal

  • Operational readiness:

    • named owners per interface

    • alerts + logs

    • retry procedures

    • “what if the file is late?” plan

Practical mitigation: Day-1 Integration Control Room

  • Hourly monitoring first 48–72 hours

  • Single tracker of failures + retries

  • Clear decision: “manual workaround vs wait for fix”

 

Monitor what can break payroll and onboarding first.

6) Reporting & Leadership Confidence: What Leaders Ask on Day 2

If leaders can’t trust numbers, they won’t trust the system.

Even when transactions work, credibility can collapse if reporting isn’t reliable.

Prepare a “Day-2 Reporting Pack”

Identify top questions and validate answers with real data:

  • Headcount by entity/country/location

  • New hires / exits this month

  • Open positions + stage distribution

  • Onboarding completion + blockers

  • Manager hierarchy accuracy

Practical mitigation: If definitions are not agreed, expect arguments instead of action. Publish metric definitions and owners.

7) Cutover: If You Didn’t Rehearse It, You Didn’t Plan It

Cutover is a timed dependency chain, not a checklist.

Minimum cutover requirements

  • Named owner per step + backup

  • Dependencies stated (“cannot start until X confirmed”)

  • Timed rehearsal (at least once)

  • Decision checkpoints (Go/No-Go gates)

Practical mitigation: Rehearse, measure durations, re-baseline the plan based on facts.

Gates prevent late surprises from becoming production incidents.

😎Hypercare: Design the Operating Model (Not Just a Team)

Hypercare fails when intake is scattered and priorities are unclear.

What strong hypercare looks like

  • One intake channel + categories

  • Daily triage call (short, disciplined)

  • Separate “defect” vs “how-to”

  • Named owners by domain:

    • EC data / workflows / RBP / integrations / Recruiting & Onboarding

  • Published response times for Week 1

Practical mitigation: Use a simple triage rule:

  • Payroll/onboarding blocker → P1

  • Access preventing critical task → P1

  • Incorrect data blocking operations → P1/P2

  • How-to → route to enablement (don’t bury the tech team)

Correct routing is your fastest Week-1 productivity gain.

Go/No-Go: Use Objective Gates (Not Optimism)

Go-live should not proceed unless these are true.

Go/No-Go Scorecard (sample)

Readiness Gate Must Be True Before Go Evidence Required Owner

Data AcceptanceThresholds metReconciliation report + sign-offHR Ops + Data Lead
RBPRoles tested end-to-endRole test pack resultsSecurity Lead
WorkflowsCore transactions passWorkflow test evidenceProcess Owner
IntegrationsMonitored + retryableControl room plan + test logsIntegration Lead
SupportHypercare readyRACI + runbooks + SLASupport Lead
Business AcceptanceRisks accepted in writingSigned risk registerBusiness Sponsor

If the business can’t sign it, it’s not a go-live decision

Week-1: What You Will See (and How to Contain It)

Even strong go-lives have issues. The goal is containment.

Likely Week-1 issues

  • Role/permission gaps for edge cases

  • Workflow routing failures for unusual org setups

  • Missed deltas / late integration files

  • Data corrections (manager/org/job info)

  • High volume “how-to” requests from managers

Containment tactics that actually work

  • Publish “Known Issues + Workarounds” daily (short list)

  • Hourly monitoring for critical interfaces (first 72 hours)

  • Rapid, controlled access patch cycle (small changes, tracked)

  • Convert repeated “how-to” into 1-page guides immediately

Ticket volume peaks early. Discipline determines how fast it drops.

Week-1 Operating Plan (Copy/Paste)

Day 0 (Go-live day)

  • Validate login across roles

  • Validate manager sees team

  • Complete 3–5 sample transactions end-to-end

  • Start integration monitoring immediately

Days 1–2

  • Triage every 2–3 hours

  • Focus: RBP blockers, stuck workflows, integration failures

Days 3–5

  • Stabilize + remove recurring root causes

  • Convert repeated “how-to” into knowledge articles

  • Keep changes small, controlled, and documented

End of Week 1

  • Publish stabilization summary:

    • ticket volumes by category

    • root causes

    • fixes deployed

    • open risks + next steps

Closing Thought

If you want go-live to feel “easy,” don’t aim for perfect configuration. Aim for operational certainty:

  • users can complete tasks

  • data is trustworthy

  • approvals flow

  • integrations are monitored and owned

  • support resolves issues fast

Discussion!

Let me know what surprised you most in Week 1 after go-live : permissions, workflows, integrations, or reporting?

See you soon with a new blog!

entry.title: Re: Integrating ABAP system with SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
To setup the required communication arrangement, you need to have the administration role. Your screenshot shows (according to the offered tiles) that you have the development role, but not the administration role. 

There is exactly one trial environment, where connectivity setup is not supported: That is the Shared Trial option (see https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/it-s-trial-time-for-abap-in-sap-business-technology-platform/ba-p/13416047 and https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-sap-btp-abap-environment-trial-account-vs-free-tier-option/ba-p/13663694). Otherwise, other users of other companies could reuse your connectivity. 

In all other trial (free tier) and commercial environments you can get (technically) the administrator role and can setup connectivity.

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD EVENT - Billing Document Created
entry.content:
Dear @gianmaria_bonvini,

Yes the Billing Document business object in Public Cloud provides business events as described on the SAP Help Portal Billing Document Events page

Link below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/28ff5a6e242249e0b82645ca26d46043.html

Best first option (no event, no API):

If your goal is simply, for example when the user creates a customer invoice, the header text should be filled automatically the cleanest approach in Public Cloud is Text Determination for Billing Header. This happens during document creation, so you avoid update after posting limitations.

In CBC look for the ID: 101292 - Set Up Text Determination for Billing Header

 

More details below:

This is the approach I’d recommend first because it stays fully standard and robust

Second option, if you still want events + API callback

Usually Yes, you need an additional license on BTP side to consume Public Cloud business events, you typically need an SAP BTP messaging service such as SAP Event Mesh or equivalent entitlement in your contract

Step by step (high-level):

  1. Create a Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0092
  2. Search for SAP_COM_0120 in Communication Arrangements
    • If available you can expose API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV for BTP callback.
    • If no the API part is likely blocked often because the scope (1Z6) item isn’t active/entitled

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462588

Example proces flow:

  1. User posts/creates the invoice in Public Cloud
  2. Public Cloud emits Billing Document Created event ->Event Mesh (via SAP_COM_0092)
  3. BTP consumes the event
  4. BTP calls API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV via SAP_COM_0120 to create/update header text

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/78da10ca6df542acb5926ac921af99e9.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/65680dabb62546029175655482f85edc.html

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV/resource/post_Cancel

Summary:

  • If the text is deterministic based on customer, sales org, payer, Incoterms, etc. use Set Up Text Determination for Billing Header in CBC is the standard way
  • Use events + API callback only if the text depends on logic/data that cannot be determined inside CBC/Public Cloud at creation time and accept that it becomes a BTP extension + API authorization topic

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: ABAP Platform in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 were released to the SAP customer base on October 8, 2025.

ABAP Platform 2025 is the technology platform underlying the release 2025 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA and is shipped as part of these products, supporting only SAP HANA database with full exploitation of its advanced capabilities. In addition,  ABAP Platform 2025 is part of SAP S/4HANA Foundation 2025 for SAP HANA-only Add-Ons.

ABAP Platform 2025 is not shipped as a standalone product. ABAP Platform 2025 consists of the AS ABAP,  the ABAP development tools for Eclipse, and several additional technology components which are required to run SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

Previous versions of SAP S/4HANA Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA such as 1610, 1709, 1809, 1909, 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023 can be upgraded directly to the 2025 release, which is based on ABAP Platform 2025 (corresponding to SAP_BASIS 816).

Product Highlights

Presentation

This presentation provides the SAP official external slide deck, just click on it to view:

Overview

ABAP Platform 2025 delivers innovations for the ABAP stack in different areas.

Clean core development

In August 2025, SAP enhanced its extensibility guidelines by introducing the new Clean core extensibility white paper. The sustainable and upgrade-safe ABAP extensibility model in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA fully relies on SAP clean core guiding principles, aiming to decouple custom extensions from SAP standard whenever possible. The refined SAP guidance for extensibility replaces binary clean core decisions with a more nuanced evaluation of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept. Evolving from the previous 3-tier model, the new extensibility model categorizes extensions into four levels (A, B, C, and D) and provides rules for ABAP classic extensions to meet the clean core level qualifications. Following this new clean core extensibility guidance the ABAP extensibility guide was updated with technical guidelines to support the clean core level concept. The ABAP extensibility model was changed from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development (level A) and classic ABAP development (levels B, C and D).

The overall clean core guidance remained unchanged: always striving for the highest possible level of extensibility. ABAP Cloud is the SAP’s recommended development model for all new custom extensions in SAP S/4HANA private cloud and on-premise systems, whereby the classic ABAP extensibility can still be used to reach clean core, with a focus on upgrade-stability and code quality. This enables SAP customers and partners to transition to a clean core incrementally and at their own speed. SAP provides guidance for ABAP clean core development by offering a recommended list of APIs (so-called “classic APIs”) to be used in classic ABAP development. For governance of ABAP clean core development, the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) now supports the clean core level concept with new ATC checks (see the blog post ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development). For governance of ABAP development for clean core in SAP S/4HANA private cloud or on-premise systems the remote ATC in SAP BTP ABAP environment is the SAP recommended approach. 

SAP Joule for Developers,  ABAP AI capabilities

SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now key components and an integral part of AI-assisted ABAP Cloud development, also facilitating custom code transformation from ECC to SAP S/4HANA. The capabilities supporting developer tasks include Joule copilot in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, predictive code completion, code explanation and unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP CDS, app and service generation (including RAP BO generation), predictive business logic for RAP BOs, and OData consumption. The provided ABAP AI SDK, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), can be utilized for the implementation of AI capabilities in custom applications.

The custom code migration capabilities include docs chat for questions around custom code migration and S/4HANA simplifications, explanation of business purpose and processing logic of legacy code (ABAP reports), explanation of S/4HANA-related ATC findings in custom code, along with resolution recommendations based on S/4HANA simplification items and cookbooks (see the blog post SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation).

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

Another major investment area in the 2025 release is the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model, which powers modern development in both ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP, enabling the creation of delightful transactional SAP Fiori apps as well as local and web APIs. This release delivers new features to accelerate and enhance the development with RAP, including new generators to boost efficiency, support of CDS table entities as persistence layer, various capabilities for SAP Fiori elements-based UIs, such as collaborative draft, cross-BO scenarios, tree views, and event-driven side effects, as well as end-to-end extensibility options.

New ABAP Cloud generators for creating OData UI services with RAP BOs (with one or more entities) from scratch, with or without AI assistance, or for generating custom UI service based on RAP BO interface are provided. ABAP CDS table entities can be used as active persistence layer for managed RAP BOs without draft, replacing classic dictionary database tables.

Enhancements for building of SAP Fiori elements-based apps with RAP include the collaborative draft handling, which allows multiple users to work simultaneously and collaboratively on the same draft instance of an entity without blocking one another. You can now also build SAP Fiori UIs that use multiple RAP BOs interacting with each other. These cross-BO scenarios rely on cross-BO transactional enablement, where the entities of the participating RAP BOs are linked through so-called cross-BO associations. Read-only and editable tree view supports displaying and manipulating hierarchical data in SAP Fiori UIs, with options for drag and drop, cut and paste, reordering, and cascading delete. Event-driven RAP side effects enable asynchronous updates in SAP Fiori UIs. When such a specific RAP business event is raised, the associated side effect is triggered, and the defined targets are reloaded in the UI.

The privileged context can now be propagated in subsequent Entity Manipulation Language (EML) requests in reading and modifying operation. Further enhancement for the behavior definitions and the behavior pools are provided with this release.

ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT)

Various enhancements are provided in ABAP development tools for Eclipse for ABAP development, RAP and ABAP CDS related development aspects, testing and troubleshooting, as well as overall IDE and productivity improvements.

Refactoring support for ABAP classes and interfaces was improved by activation of renaming changes by default, validation of new names and displaying long texts of exceptions. The new where-used dialog enables prefiltering of search results to focus on usages relevant for the concrete use case. There is a new property abaplv to filter object searches with the ABAP language version. There are new editors like for example for working with software component relations, Adobe Forms or maintaining intelligent scenarios and intelligent scenarios models which are required to run a solution based on generative AI. It is possible to create and edit CDS table entities and create for them behavior definitions.

In the area of ABAP unit tests, method calls in test classes can now be highlighted in different colors to distinguish their method contexts. Quick actions allow tests to be launched or templates for test classes to be inserted with a single mouse click. The failed assertions and status of test methods can be displayed directly in the source code editor. The unit tests can be rerun with coverage and coverage results can be cleared in the ABAP Coverage view. Additionally, there is a new AMDP Test Double Framework, and the CDS Test Double Framework now supports CDS hierarchy views.

In the ABAP debugger, it is now possible to display the memory consumption of a debugged ABAP program in the new ABAP Memory (Debugger) view. The ABAP Memory Snapshot view lists all memory snapshots, which can be opened in the editor to show memory objects ranked by size. These views make it easier to analyze the memory usage of an ABAP application. Internal tables can now be easily compared using the table comparison tool within the ABAP debugger. Beyond this, the ABAP debugger can now consider variables with hidden values (for sensitive data), display variables of type JSON, and show component groups for nested structures in the Variables view. Collaborative error analysis is supported by export/import of ABAP Cross Trace results to/from JSON file or export of short dumps as ZIP file in the ABAP Runtime Error Viewer.

Beyond this there are also enhancements in transport management for adding an object to a transport or searching and grouping transport requests.

ABAP Language

The modern, declarative, and expression-oriented ABAP language allows writing simple and concise ABAP code through features such as inline declarations and constructor expressions. Advanced operations for internal tables include grouping, filtering, and the CORRESPONDING( ) operator. The cloud-optimized version “ABAP for Cloud Development” is used for ABAP Cloud development.

There are further enhancements for internal tables, including support for arbitrary logical expressions and equality conditions, as well as harmonization of table expressions and READ TABLE statement. New ABAP system classes for probability distributions are provided, enabling the generation of random number and the calculation of quantile, probabilities, and other aspects. These classes support various discrete and continuous distributions. This release also delivers enhancements for expressions and functions, as well as for transformations, such as the new domain XSDGEO for serializing and deserializing spatial data between the Extended Well-Known Binary (EWKB) representation and the GeoJSON format.

SAP HANA-centric optimizations & Data Integration scenarios

Modern ABAP development on SAP HANA has been enhanced with several advanced, database-centric features also enriching data integration scenarios. Recent innovations in data integration focus on data exposure, including ABAP-managed database procedures for advanced read scenarios.  With CDS updatable view entities it is now possible to wrap existing DDIC database tables (or CDS table entities) and expose a native CDS signature, which can be used with ABAP SQL in combination with DCL-based access control. 

On the consumption side, new write scenarios, the use of static CDS external entities, and the possibility to create ABAP CDS models based on imported CDS models make it easier than ever to integrate external data seamlessly into an ABAP CDS view stack.

Additional enhancements, such as CDS table entities to define and manage SAP HANA database tables as native CDS repository objects, a CDS generation wizard to simplify and automate the creation of hierarchically structured data in ABAP CDS, and AI-powered CDS Explain to get semantical context information about CDS entities further brighten the ABAP development landscape.

Embedded analytics

For embedded analytics scenarios it is now possible to expedite development workflow using ABAP Cloud generator wizards for creation of multidimensional analysis apps, Review Booklet apps, or native CDS hierarchy definitions. With the introduction of reusable measures and filters, the key figures, measures, filters and many more features can now be defined centrally, based on user needs to better manage and align analytical reporting. They can also be utilized in CDS view entities to ensure homogenous definition of complex calculations and unification of coherences of the running business.

Event Enablement & Business Events

The event-driven architecture of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA is strengthened, and the interoperability across enterprise solutions is improved through seamless integration with SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan and support of SAP Cloud Application Event Hub to consume events published by SAP Order Management Foundation on SAP BTP.

The event-driven processing and monitoring was enhanced with new outbound event filtering, enabling selective publishing based on configurable criteria, and dynamic topics in SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan for more efficient routing. Operational transparency was improved through comprehensive event logging, including local capture and logging of successfully processed events. Events of the same type and object within a session can now be grouped as activities, improving traceability and reducing monitoring noise. Together, these features provide a scalable and well-governed foundation for event-driven architecture.

Process integration & Connectivity

Key highlights of process integration include a robust OData service consumption model with Swagger UI preview and advanced OData V4 capabilities, such as bulk processing and asynchronous communication integrated with AIF. The API governance and communication management was enhanced by introducing Communication Targets within Communication Arrangements, enabling more granular control over connectivity endpoints. API lifecycle management is improved through API-to-package assignment and the ability to create API packages for better organization across API types. Additionally, OData-based access to Communication Management data increases automation, transparency, and integration with external tools.

Additional connectivity improvements include outbound communication enablement via HTTP and RFC, support for setting the AIR key as a custom HTTP header in SOAP requests for more secure message handling, direct push-based data exchange between ABAP systems via RFC, and SSE support in the ABAP HTTP client and server for efficient real-time event delivery in distributed scenarios.

Key user extensibility

Further improvements are provided for key user extensibility. It is now possible to generate a Fiori elements application for a custom business object with just one click and maintain behavior extensions for SAP-provided RAP business objects using key user extensibility. Moreover, using developer extensibility it is now possible to implement feature control for custom fields that were created via the Custom Fields app. The new extension field wizard provides a better development efficiency by boosting the creation of custom fields via developer extensibility.

Security

Key updates include support for OAuth Authorization Code with PKCE (RFC 7636) and JWT-based client authentication (RFC 7523), as well as SAP-managed client certificates for secure integration in S/4HANA Private Cloud (2025 FPS01). TLS 1.3 is now supported across HTTP, WebSocket RFC, and SMTP, with OAuth Client Credential Grant enabled for SMTP outbound scenarios such as Exchange Online.

Additional enhancements include new OpenID Connect features, improved troubleshooting guidance (SAP Note 3111813), and a new OAuth Client Configuration UI (SOAUTH_CLIENT) with built-in testing and token metadata display.

entry.title: From Roles to Skills: A Modern Hiring Approach with SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Unprecedented global changes are reshaping how organizations think about their hiring strategy approach making skills become one of top trends in 2025.  

According to research, the demand for new skills is expected to grow up to 65% per year by 2030 due to advancements in AI. At the same time, 81% of employers globally are already using skills-based hiring, and the growing skills gap is driving the need for specialized, on-demand talent. As a result, organizations are shifting from traditional hiring practices to Skills-Based Hiring. 

What is Skills-Based Hiring? A skills-based approach means that hiring decisions are made based on a candidate’s skills and ability to perform a job—rather than solely on formal qualifications such as education or previous job titles listed on their résumé or CV. 

Why does Skills-Based Hiring Matters? 

The world of work is evolving rapidly. Organizations today face unprecedented challenges—labour shortages, digital transformation, and the need for agility. 
Skills-based hiring helps businesses focus on what truly matters: the capabilities required to deliver outcomes, not just credentials. 

With a skills-based approach, organizations can address not only their current talent needs but also long-term workforce strategies. It helps anticipate future requirements and stay ahead of the competition. 

Benefits of Skill-Based Hiring 

  • Increase workforce diversity by expanding talent pools and removing unconscious bias  
  • Accelerate hiring decisions and streamline recruitment by reducing time to fill 
  • Boost productivity and reduce cost by aligning the right skills with the right roles 
  • Improve transparency for candidates by increasing visibility on role selection criteria 
  • Enhance fairness and compliance through more equitable, data-driven decisions 

Strong capabilities in SAP Fieldglass 

SAP Fieldglass has introduced powerful innovations to make skills-based hiring a reality: 

  • AI-Assisted Job Posting Creation: Generative AI now helps craft job descriptions and translate them into multiple languages, ensuring global reach and consistency.  
  • AI-powered Recommended Qualifications: Machine learning suggests relevant skills and qualifications for job postings based on historical data and market trends. This reduces manual effort and ensures competitive requisitions.  
  • Resume Skill Extraction & Matching: AI algorithms automatically extract skills from resumes, anonymise personal data, and rank candidates based on skill match scores—helping hiring managers make unbiased, data-driven decisions.  
  • Resume Assessment: AI algorithms evaluate resumes against job requirements across multiple dimensions—skills, experience, qualifications, and industry background—to generate an overall match score. 
  • Integrated Skills Libraries & AI generated skill library: Synchronisation between SAP Fieldglass and SAP SuccessFactors enables unified skill tracking across internal and external talent pools, supporting holistic workforce planning. And automated creation of skills library via AI. 
  • Joule AI Assistant: Embedded conversational AI simplifies tasks such as to find job templates and generating job descriptions—streamlining the hiring workflow.  
  • Flexible skills Assessment: Configure custom evaluation scales for assessing individual skills. Instead of rigid templates, companies can tailor skill assessments to match specific roles or project needs, improving precision in evaluating contingent workers. 
  • Skill Benchmarking Analytics: Search jobs and skills in any industry, city and county to run side-by-side comparison in a location simulation to identify the best place to hire. 

Analytics & Insights: Driving Smarter Workforce Decisions 

Skills-based hiring is only as effective as the insights behind it. SAP Fieldglass provides advanced analytics that go beyond simple reporting—offering predictive intelligence to shape workforce strategies. Organisations can access skill gap dashboards to identify critical shortages, leverage benchmarking tools to compare candidate capabilities against role requirements and use trend analysis to forecast future skill demands. These insights empower HR and procurement teams to make data-driven decisions, prioritise upskilling initiatives, and optimise sourcing strategies.  

How It Fits into Total Workforce Strategy Picture 

Skills-based hiring isn’t just a recruitment trend—it’s a cornerstone of Total Workforce Management (TWM). With nearly 50% of the workforce now contingent, organisations need visibility and control across all worker types: full-time employees, freelancers, contractors, and service providers.   

SAP Fieldglass, integrated with SAP SuccessFactors, delivers: 

  • Unified Data Models for internal and external workers. 
  • Centralised Visibility into skills, positions, and requisitions. 
  • Compliance Automation to manage global labour regulations. 
  • Analytics for Skill Gaps to inform upskilling and reskilling strategies.  

This synergy breaks down silos between HR and Procurement, enabling organisations to optimise cost, reduce risk, and respond quickly to market changes.  

What’s Next? 

SAP Fieldglass continues to innovate with: 

  • AI-Enhanced Candidate Recommendations: Leverage AI to identify top candidates faster by analyzing skills, experience, and fit. 
  • Centralize qualifications: Consolidate fragmented qualification libraries into a centralised, AI-enabled hub, ensuring consistency and transparency across all buyer networks.  
  • Enhanced Talent Pool Connectivity: Seamlessly connect direct sourcing with talent pools for proactive candidate engagement.  

These capabilities position SAP Fieldglass as a leader in workforce transformation—helping organisations win the race for skills in a competitive market. 

In conclusion, if you want to build a Future-Proofing: Build a workforce ready for emerging technologies and roles. With the enough agility. Nearly 90% of HR leaders believe that up to half of their workforce will need to be reskilled in the next five years due to AI uptake alone.

Ready to embrace skills-based hiring? Explore SAP Fieldglass and SAP SuccessFactors for a unified approach to Total Workforce Management.  

For more details on each use case please visit: Smarter Skills-Based Hiring with SAP Fieldglass - SAP Community

entry.title: 【EventReport】ASUG Tech Connect 2025：SAP TechEdの「北米ツアー」が示す、技術と人の変革
entry.content:
(※English translation is available in the latter half of this article.)

※免責事項

本稿はJSUGテクニカル部会オピニオンリーダーとしての経験に基づく個人の見解であり、個人の所属企業およびJSUG等の組織の公式な見解を代表するものではありません。また文書の一部は生成AIにより作成しています。内容の正確性などを保証するものではありませんので、情報の活用はご自身の判断で行ってください。

この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月15日分の記事として執筆しています。

はじめに：技術の「本流」と、コミュニティの「熱源」を求めて

先日、ケンタッキー州ルイビルにて「ASUG Tech Connect 2025」が開催されました。

今年で3回目を迎える本イベントですが、私たちJSUG（ジャパンSAPユーザーグループ）テクニカル部会は、初年度（2023年）から欠かさず参加し、現地の熱量を定点観測しています。

今年、JSUGテクニカル部会は戦略的なアプローチをとりました。

SAPの最新技術が発表される本家「SAP TechEd Berlin」には2名のメンバーを派遣し、技術の「本流」をキャッチアップする一方、ここ北米の「ASUG Tech Connect」には私を含む3名を派遣しました。

なぜ、私たちはあえてチームを分け、北米にも足を運んだのか？

かつて北米のSAP TechEdがバーチャル化した際、「対面で集まる場が必要だ」という現地の強い意志で生まれたのがこのイベントです。現在はSAP TechEdも対面開催が復活しましたが、ASUG Tech Connectは**「人が集まることの意義」**を何よりも重視するイベントとして、独自の進化を遂げています。

最新技術（Berlin）と、その実践・コミュニティ（ASUG）。

双方にメンバーを派遣したからこそ見えてきた、SAP TechEdとの連携内容と、ASUGならではの「人の変革」に向けたメッセージをレポートします。

1. SAP TechEd Berlinとの強力な連携：海を越えた「完璧な伴走者」

ASUG Tech Connectは、今年、SAP TechEdと**「完璧な伴走者（The perfect companions）」であると明確に定義されました。これは、「北米における公式なSAP TechEdツアーイベント」**として、以下の3点でグローバルイベントと完全に同期しているためです。

  • コンテンツの共有（ハンズオン）：

    SAP TechEd Berlinで発表された技術セッションやハンズオン資料が、そのまま北米会場でも提供されました。例えば、生成AIやFioriアプリ開発のセッションでは、「SAP TechEd Berlinからのハンズオンを試す」という案内が含まれており、北米にいながらベルリンと同じ技術体験が可能となっています。

  • 認定資格の提供：

    会場では「SAP Build Developer」や「SAP Generative AI Developer」といった最新のSAP認定資格を、追加費用なしで取得できる機会が提供されました。

  • リアルタイムの連携：

    キーノートでは、SAPのMuhammad Alam氏がベルリンのSAP TechEd会場から中継で参加。物理的な距離を超えて、両イベントが一体的なメッセージを発信していることが強調されました。

 

 

2. キーノートの核心：技術よりも「人」を変革せよ

イベントのハイライトであるキーノートは、初日の「オープニング」と3日目の「パートナー・顧客事例」の2部構成で行われました。

ここでASUG CEOのGeoff Scott氏とSAPのリーダーたちが発信したのは、単なる新機能の紹介にとどまらない、私たちのキャリアと組織の存続に関わる強烈なメッセージでした。ここが、技術発表中心のSAP TechEdとの最も大きな違いです。

「変化の速度は、もう二度と遅くならない」

まず共有したいのは、イベント全体を通して繰り返し引用された、現代を象徴するフレーズです。

「変化の速度はかつてないほど速く、かつ今後これほど遅くなることは二度とない」

（Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again）

私たちは今、歴史的な転換点にいます。

顧客パネルでは、「グーテンベルクの印刷機普及に500年かかったのに対し、ChatGPTはわずか5日で100万ユーザーに到達した」という事実が対比されました。

また、SAPのMayank Shrivastava氏は、AIモデルの進化サイクルが「恐ろしいペース（frightening pace）」であるとし、以前は約10ヶ月だった更新間隔が、最新モデルではわずか7週間に短縮されていると指摘しました。

この**「不可逆的な加速」**の中で、私たちはどう振る舞うべきでしょうか？

「昨日」を捨て、「Learn-it-all」へ

この問いに対し、SAPのGlobal Head of AIであるDr. Walter Sun氏は、2つの重要な指針を示しました。

1. 昨日と同じ最適化をやめる

「昨日やってきたことを最適化するのをやめるべき（Stop optimizing what we have done yesterday）」

既存のプロセスをAIで単に効率化するのではなく、プロセスそのものを根本から再考し、実験（Experimentation）する好奇心が不可欠です。

2. 「Know-it-all」から「Learn-it-all」へ

そして、マインドセットの変革として提示されたのが**「Learn-it-all」**です。

  • Know-it-all（全てを知る者）： 過去の知識に固執し、自分が全てを知っていると過信する姿勢。

  • Learn-it-all（全てを学ぶ者）： 毎日新しいことを学ぼうとする姿勢。

AIは参入障壁が低く、誰でもすぐに試せます。だからこそ、知識量ではなく**「試して学ぶ（Experimentation）」サイクルを回せるかどうか**が勝負の分かれ目となります。

技術とチームによる支援

もちろん、精神論だけではありません。具体的な「武器」と「事例」も共有されました。

  • 開発者への武器：

    Muhammad Alam氏とYaad Oren氏は、7週間単位の変化に対応するため、**「クリーンなデータレイヤー（Business Data Cloud）」への投資が最重要であるとしました。また、バックログ解消のためSAP Buildのオープン化（VS Code拡張など）**が発表され、開発者が使い慣れたツールで戦える環境が約束されました。

  • 変革はチームスポーツである：

    3日目のキーノートでは、PepsiCo（AI/Copilot活用）、HP（ERPモダナイゼーション）、Int4（テスト自動化）などの事例が共有されました。

    特にJohn Deere社などによる**「Show and Tell」セッションでは、きれいなスライドだけでなく、チーム全体でどう課題を乗り越えたかという「泥臭い実践知」**が実演され、ASUGならではのリアリティある学びの場となっていました。

 

 

 

3. 分析：SAP TechEd BerlinとASUG Tech Connectの違いとは？

BerlinとASUG、双方に参加したJSUGメンバーの視点を総合すると、両イベントは**「同じ技術戦略（What）」を共有しながらも、「誰に、どう伝えるか（Who & How）」**において明確な役割分担がなされていることがわかります。

共通点（The "What"）

両イベント共に、技術的なコアメッセージは完全に一致しています。

  • AIエージェントの時代： チャットボットを超えた「自律型AI（Joule Agents）」への注力。

  • 開発者への開放（Openness）： SAP BuildのVS Code拡張機能など、オープンな標準技術との融合。

  • Clean Core： イノベーションの基盤としての「クリーンなデータレイヤー」とBTPの活用。

相違点（The "Focus"）

しかし、その焦点は大きく異なります。

特徴SAP TechEd Berlin (Global)ASUG Tech Connect (North America)
キャッチメッセージWhere ideas get real.Real Skills. Real People. Real Impact.
主眼「テクノロジーとロードマップ」「プロフェッショナルの変革」
AIの視点機能と可能性（AIで何ができるか）責任とスキル（人がどうAIを使いこなすか）
事例SAP技術のショーケース泥臭い実践知の共有（Show and Tell）
方向性ベンダーからユーザーへ（Vision）ユーザー同士の相互扶助（Community）

つまり、Berlinが**「最新の武器（技術）」を渡す場であるのに対し、ASUG Tech Connectは「使い手（人）」**を育てる場であると言えます。

 

 

 

まとめ：同じ悩みを抱える今だからこそ、日本のコミュニティを盛り上げよう

「ビジネス変革は、プロフェッショナル変革なしには起こらない」

（Business transformation does not happen without professional transformation）

これは、ASUG Tech Connectのオープニング・キーノートにおいて、ASUG CEOであるGeoff Scott氏によって語られた言葉です。

テクノロジー（AIやS/4HANA）を導入するだけではビジネスは変わらない。それを扱う我々自身が、古い習慣を捨てて新しいスキルとマインドセットを身につけること（＝プロフェッショナル変革）が、成功の絶対条件だからです。

しかし、私たち個人には、AIによる能力拡張への希望がある一方、常に学び続ける「Learn-it-all」への変革が求められる不安もあるかと思います。

さらに、組織に目を向ければ、データの整備、文化的な受容、セキュリティ責任など、一筋縄ではいかない壁が立ちはだかっています。

今回の参加を通じて、私は皆様にどうしてもお伝えしたい、ある「現実」を見つけました。

会場で最新技術に触れる一方、ASUG Communityのメンバーとネットワーキングをする中で、彼らの口からこぼれたのは、意外な言葉でした。

「既存システムの保守に忙殺されていて、新しい技術に手が回らない」

「変革が必要なのはわかっているが、組織がついてこない」

IT先進国と言われる北米の技術者でさえ、実際には私たちと全く同じ悩みを抱え、現在進行形の問題と戦っていたのです。

「変化の速度はかつてないほど速い」というキーノートの警告は、彼らにとってもまた、重くのしかかる現実でした。

私たちは、一人ではありません。そして、日本だけが遅れているわけでもありません。

世界中が同じ壁に直面している今、ASUGのCEOであるGeoff Scott氏が投げかけた問いの意味が、より一層強く響きます。

"Why go alone when we can go together?"

（一緒に行けるのに、なぜ一人で行くのですか？）

どれほど優秀な個人のスキルがあろうとも、この激流の中で孤立して戦うことのリスクはあまりに大きすぎます。

北米のユーザーがASUGという場に集まり、お互いに支え合おうとしているように、私たちもまた、日本のコミュニティの力をもっと強くする必要があります。

ここSAP Communityはもちろん、社外の勉強会、オンラインのフォーラム、パートナーコミュニティ、そして私たちのようなユーザーグループ。日本には多様な「つながる場」があります。

今回私たちがBerlinと北米で掴んできた知見も、様々な機会を通じて共有させていただきます。日本のコミュニティ全体をもっと盛り上げ、互いに知恵を出し合い（Collective wisdom）、この変化の波を一緒に乗り越えていきましょう。

様々なコミュニティの場で、皆様と熱く議論できることを楽しみにしています。

[English Version]

Event Report: ASUG Tech Connect 2025: JSUG Technical Committee's Perspective on the SAP Ecosystem via Berlin and North America

Disclaimer:

This article represents the personal views of the author based on their experience as an Opinion Leader of the JSUG Technical Committee and does not represent the official views of their affiliated company or organizations such as JSUG. Parts of this document were created with the assistance of Generative AI. We do not guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.

This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025 (December 15th).

Introduction: Seeking the "Mainstream" of Technology and the "Heat Source" of Community

Recently, "ASUG Tech Connect 2025" was held in Louisville, Kentucky.

Although this is the third year for this event, we at the JSUG (Japan SAP Users' Group) Technical Committee have participated every year since its inception (2023), regularly monitoring the enthusiasm and trends on the ground.

This year, the JSUG Technical Committee took a strategic approach.

We dispatched two members to "SAP TechEd Berlin," the main event where SAP's latest technologies are announced, to catch up on the "mainstream" of technology. Meanwhile, we dispatched three members, including myself, to "ASUG Tech Connect" here in North America.

Why did we dare to split the team and travel to North America?

This event was born out of a strong local will that "a place for face-to-face gathering is necessary" when SAP TechEd in North America became virtual in the past. Although SAP TechEd has now returned to in-person formats, ASUG Tech Connect has undergone its own unique evolution as an event that prioritizes "the significance of people gathering" above all else.

The latest technology (Berlin) and its practice/community (ASUG).

We report on the collaboration with SAP TechEd and the message unique to ASUG regarding "Human Transformation," which became visible precisely because we dispatched members to both sides.

 

 

 

1. Powerful Collaboration with SAP TechEd Berlin: The "Perfect Companions" Across the Ocean

This year, ASUG Tech Connect was clearly defined as "The perfect companions" to SAP TechEd. This is because, as "The Official North American SAP TechEd Tour Event," it is completely synchronized with the global event in the following three points:

  • Sharing Content (Hands-on):

    Technical sessions and hands-on materials announced at SAP TechEd Berlin were provided as-is at the North American venue. For example, sessions on Generative AI and Fiori app development included guidance to "Try the hands-on from SAP TechEd Berlin," enabling the same technical experience as in Berlin while being in North America.

  • Providing Certification:

    The venue offered opportunities to obtain the latest SAP certifications such as "SAP Build Developer" and "SAP Generative AI Developer" at no additional cost.

  • Real-time Collaboration:

    In the keynote, SAP's Muhammad Alam participated via live broadcast from the SAP TechEd venue in Berlin. It was emphasized that both events are transmitting a unified message, transcending physical distance.

 

 

 

2. The Core of the Keynote: Transform "People" Rather Than Technology

The keynote, the highlight of the event, consisted of two parts: the "Opening" on the first day and the "Partner & Customer Stories" on the third day.

What ASUG CEO Geoff Scott and SAP leaders broadcasted here was a powerful message concerning our careers and the survival of our organizations, going beyond mere introductions of new features. This is the biggest difference from SAP TechEd, which focuses on technology announcements.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

First, I want to share a phrase that symbolizes the modern era, which was repeatedly cited throughout the event.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

We are now at a historical turning point.

In the customer panel, a fact was contrasted: "It took 500 years for Gutenberg's printing press to spread, whereas ChatGPT reached 1 million users in just 5 days."

Also, SAP's Mayank Shrivastava pointed out that the evolution cycle of AI models is at a "frightening pace," shortening from an update interval of about 10 months previously to just 7 weeks for the latest models.

In this "irreversible acceleration," how should we behave?

Discard "Yesterday" and Move to "Learn-it-all"

In response to this question, Dr. Walter Sun, SAP's Global Head of AI, presented two important guidelines.

  1. Stop Optimizing Yesterday

    "Stop optimizing what we have done yesterday."

    It is essential not to merely improve efficiency of existing processes with AI, but to rethink the processes themselves from the ground up and have the curiosity to experiment.

  2. From "Know-it-all" to "Learn-it-all"

    Then, "Learn-it-all" was presented as the mindset transformation.

    • Know-it-all: An attitude of clinging to past knowledge and being overconfident that one knows everything.

    • Learn-it-all: An attitude of trying to learn new things every day.

    Barriers to entry for AI are low, and anyone can try it immediately. That is why whether you can cycle through "Experimentation" becomes the dividing line for victory, rather than the amount of knowledge.

Support through Technology and Teams

Of course, it was not just about mindset. Concrete "weapons" and "cases" were also shared.

  • Weapons for Developers:

    Muhammad Alam and Yaad Oren stated that investment in a "Clean Data Layer (Business Data Cloud)" is paramount to respond to changes happening in 7-week units. Also, the opening of SAP Build (VS Code extensions, etc.) was announced to resolve backlogs, promising an environment where developers can fight using familiar tools.

  • Transformation is a Team Sport:

    In the keynote on the third day, cases such as PepsiCo (AI/Copilot utilization), HP (ERP modernization), and Int4 (test automation) were shared.

    In particular, the "Show and Tell" sessions by companies like John Deere demonstrated not just clean slides but the "gritty practical knowledge" of how the whole team overcame challenges, serving as a learning ground with reality unique to ASUG.

 

 

 

3. Analysis: What is the Difference Between SAP TechEd Berlin and ASUG Tech Connect?

Synthesizing the perspectives of JSUG members who participated in both Berlin and ASUG, we can see that while both events share the "Same Technology Strategy (What)," there is a clear division of roles in "Who they tell it to and How (Who & How)."

Commonalities (The "What")

Both events are completely aligned on technical core messages.

  • The Era of AI Agents: Focus on "Autonomous AI (Joule Agents)" beyond chatbots.

  • Openness to Developers: Fusion with open standard technologies such as SAP Build VS Code extensions.

  • Clean Core: Utilization of "Clean Data Layer" and BTP as the foundation for innovation.

Differences (The "Focus")

However, their focus differs significantly.

FeatureSAP TechEd Berlin (Global)ASUG Tech Connect (North America)
Catch MessageWhere ideas get real.Real Skills. Real People. Real Impact.
Main Focus"Technology and Roadmap""Professional Transformation"
Perspective on AIFunctionality and Possibility (What AI can do)Responsibility and Skills (How humans use AI)
Case StudiesShowcase of SAP TechnologySharing Gritty Practical Knowledge (Show and Tell)
DirectionVendor to User (Vision)User to User Mutual Aid (Community)

In other words, while Berlin is a place to hand over the "Latest Weapons (Technology)," ASUG Tech Connect can be said to be a place to nurture the "Users (People)."

 

 

 

 

 

 

Summary: Let's Energize the Japanese Community Precisely Because We Share the Same Struggles

"Business transformation does not happen without professional transformation"

This phrase was spoken by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott in the opening keynote of ASUG Tech Connect.

Implementing technology (AI or S/4HANA) alone does not change business. It is an absolute condition for success that we, who handle it, discard old habits and acquire new skills and mindsets (= professional transformation).

However, while we individuals have hope for capability expansion through AI, I think there is also anxiety about being required to transform into a constantly learning "Learn-it-all."

Furthermore, looking at organizations, we face walls that are not easily overcome, such as data preparation, cultural acceptance, and security responsibilities.

Through this participation, I found a certain "reality" that I desperately want to convey to you all.

While touching on the latest technology at the venue, networking with ASUG Community members revealed unexpected words from them.

"We are busy with the maintenance of existing systems and cannot get around to new technologies."

"We know transformation is necessary, but the organization doesn't follow."

Even engineers in North America, which is said to be an IT-advanced region, were actually facing exactly the same worries as us and fighting ongoing problems.

The keynote's warning that "Change has never been this fast" was a heavy reality for them as well.

We are not alone. And it is not just Japan that is lagging behind.

Now that the whole world is facing the same wall, the meaning of the question thrown by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott resonates even more strongly.

"Why go alone when we can go together?"

No matter how excellent individual skills are, the risk of fighting in isolation in this torrent is too great.

Just as users in North America are gathering at ASUG to support each other, we also need to strengthen the power of the Japanese community more.

There are diverse "places to connect" in Japan: not just the SAP Community here, but also external study groups, online forums, partner communities, and user groups like ours.

We will share the insights we grabbed in Berlin and North America through various opportunities. Let's energize the entire Japanese community, share wisdom with each other (Collective wisdom), and ride over this wave of change together.

I look forward to heating up the discussion with you all at various community venues.
